36. Toppings, Jane (Mrs. William H.)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name: Anna Jane Stoffel
Address: 817 Broadview Ave.
Birthplace: Germany

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1889
Where did you set up housekeeping? With my brother
Where had you been living before that? Oregon
For how many people did you prepare meals? Two
How far was it to your nearest store? Twenty
How often could a visit be made to the store? We didn't go very often
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, tea, rolled oats, preserves & evaporated apples

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? S.H. Farmers
In what quantities did you buy? 3 or 6 bags at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 25
What year? 1890
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use? None
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? It was mostly always pork.
How did you get fresh meat? We had fresh meat when it was first butchered then it was salted.
How often did you get fresh meat? Sometimes smoked.
How did you preserve meat? Salted and cured.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.
If so what year was it organized? 1915.
Did you use game? What kinds? Mostly deer.

For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? We sometimes got fish in early spring (fresh).
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?
Kinds? Salted, brining, or cold.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

In 1893 a prairie fire burned our stable, 2 horses (all the horses we had you went to meet), a new brooder (only $5 paid for), a new house, all our vegetables were in a wood-house, new barn a 100 bus we expected to sell having us 3 hogs (we had in house). We had 10 broods, turnips lost in fire too. The turnips were fed to cattle in winter due to shortage of water.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

In 1918 a friend of mine had a hard time. He was working in a hard labor camp near a town in British Columbia. We had no food. We had to eat grass and roots. We had to eat snow. We had to eat water.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

In 1892 we made butter and milk in pans in milk house & skimmed the cream top. I made butter packed in tubes of 60 lb. & traded at for groceries in town 25 miles away getting 10¢ & 12¢ for it.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and homemade foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of storage, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (One blank page if more space is needed).

In 1894 we made butter all our own. We had a cow and milked her twice a day. We also had chickens and eggs. We preserved our own vegetables by canning and freezing. We also had a garden and grew our own vegetables. We bought flour, sugar, and other staples from the local store. We also had a wood stove and cooked our meals over an open fire. We used kerosene lamps for lighting. We also had a well and drew water from it.
